item.title: We sought to understand how one specific factor, optical resolution, affects the resolution of photostimulation under specific conditions: spiral scanning C1V1-Kv2.1 expressing neurons with a low repetition rate (2 MHz) laser.

item.title: We held all variables constant in the experiment except for the optical resolution of the system, which we varied using a spatial light modulator to underfill the back aperture of the objective. item.title: A key take-home message is that cell size and shape determine the spatial precision under these conditions. This is confirmed by a simple model convolving the optical PSF with a cell and showing how the size of the cell dictates the physiological PSF above a certain size. https://t.co/5TPEe3ryFG

item.title: @paqio I would expect broadening to be the same for both PSF sizes, kind of an additive effect. E.g., if the broading by scattering is 5 um, FWHMs could be 13 and 24 um - the relative broadening would be stronger for the smaller PSF. But I have no data on that, it's just my intuition.
item.description: @paqio I would expect broadening to be the same for both PSF sizes, kind of an additive effect. E.g., if the broading by scattering is 5 um, FWHMs could be 13 and 24 um - the relative broadening would be stronger for the smaller PSF. But I have no data on that, it's just my intuition.
item.content:encoded: @paqio I would expect broadening to be the same for both PSF sizes, kind of an additive effect. E.g., if the broading by scattering is 5 um, FWHMs could be 13 and 24 um - the relative broadening would be stronger for the smaller PSF. But I have no data on that, it's just my intuition.
